title: Spicy Pulled Pork Ramen
summary: The recipe Spicy Pulled Pork Ramen could satisfy your Japanese craving in approximately 30 minutes. One serving contains 335 calories, 33g of protein, and 18g of fat. This recipe serves 4 and costs $2.4 per serving. 252 people have made this recipe and would make it again. If you have sesame seeds, pulled pork shoulder, soy sauce, and a few other ingredients on hand, you can make it. To use up the unsalted butter you could follow this main course with the Almond Milk Chocolate Pudding as a dessert. It works well as a rather cheap main course. All things considered, we decided this recipe deserves a spoonacular score of 86%. This score is outstanding. Try 20 Minute Sweet & Spicy Pork Ramen Stir Fry, Spicy Pop Pulled Pork, and Hot N' Spicy Mango Pulled Pork for similar recipes.

winePairing.pairingText: Riesling, Sake, and Sauvignon Blanc are great choices for Ramen Noodles. Saké is an obvious choice when it comes to Japanese food. If you want to stick to grape wine, though, you might opt for sauvignon blanc or riesling. One wine you could try is Alsace Willm Kirchberg de Barr Riesling. It has 4.8 out of 5 stars and a bottle costs about 24 dollars.

productMatches.title: Alsace Willm Kirchberg de Barr Riesling
productMatches.description: The Grand Cru Kirchberg de Barr is one of the most renowned Grands Crus of Alsace, which gives rise to Riesling of great character. The terroir is deep, giving wines excellent structure, freshness and unparalleled aromatic intensity. Over time, these wines gain particularly in complexity, finesse and minerality.

instructions: First, if you want to cook pork specifically for this recipe, I recommend this oven roasted version or this slow cooker version.Heat a large skillet over medium heat and add the butter. Once melted, add the mushrooms and garlic and toss. Cook until the mushrooms are soft and juicy, about 5 minutes. Set aside.While the mushrooms are cooking, bring the stock to a simmer. Stir in the soy sauce and hoisin sauce. Cook your eggs too! I like to soft boil mine - but poaching is good too. Place the ramen blocks in two large bowls. Add the pork, scallions and a few cucumber slices to each bowl. Pour the stock over both blocks evenly and let sit for 2 to 3 minutes before stirring. Add mushrooms to each bowl and stir in a few more cucumber slices. At this point you could separate into two more bowls if you want 4 servings. Stir in the chili garlic paste (I do about a tablespoon per bowl for SPICY!) and add your egg and nori sheets. Sprinkle with sesame seeds and drizzle with toasted sesame oil. Serve immediately.

steps.step: First, if you want to cook pork specifically for this recipe, I recommend this oven roasted version or this slow cooker version.

Heat a large skillet over medium heat and add the butter. Once melted, add the mushrooms and garlic and toss. Cook until the mushrooms are soft and juicy, about 5 minutes. Set aside.While the mushrooms are cooking, bring the stock to a simmer. Stir in the soy sauce and hoisin sauce. Cook your eggs too! I like to soft boil mine - but poaching is good too.
Place the ramen blocks in two large bowls.
Add the pork, scallions and a few cucumber slices to each bowl.
Pour the stock over both blocks evenly and let sit for 2 to 3 minutes before stirring.

Add mushrooms to each bowl and stir in a few more cucumber slices. At this point you could separate into two more bowls if you want 4 servings. Stir in the chili garlic paste (I do about a tablespoon per bowl for SPICY!) and add your egg and nori sheets.
Sprinkle with sesame seeds and drizzle with toasted sesame oil.
